questions.text: A 27-year-old woman comes to the physician to discuss her appetite. The patient tells the physician that for the last one and a half months she has been eating ice “nearly every day,” stating that she has intense cravings for it. Her appetite is otherwise normal, and she feels her weight has been stable over this time period. Apart from these cravings, she says her life is “completely normal,” and that she functions well at her job and is taking care of her 5-year old son. She does not have any history of mental illness. Family history is noncontributory. Which of the following is most likely to be found on further evaluation?

choices.text: Air fluid levels on abdominal radiography
Large blasts on peripheral blood smear

questions.solution:
This patient is having ice cravings and is repeatedly eating ice, suggesting a diagnosis of pica. Pica is defined as eating non-nutritive, non-food substances, which can include mud, ice, paper, or charcoal. For the diagnosis of pica to be made, this behavior must persist for at least 1 month and should not be socially or culturally acceptable behavior. Additionally, pica is not diagnosed in children less than the age of 2 years, as eating non-nutritive substances is part of normal pediatric development – it is common and not considered pathological.  



The etiology of pica is not completely understood, however, certain patients are at increased risk of developing the condition. For instance, it is seen more in children and pregnant women. Additionally, iron deficiency has also been implicated in patients with pica, especially for ice. Other nutritional deficiencies like zinc deficiency can also cause pica. Finally, other risk factors include stress and underlying mental illness.  


The evaluation and treatment of pica can be different. First of all, iron studies must be done to check for iron deficiency anemia, and if found, supplementation with iron supplements is usually enough for the treatment. Other nutritional deficiencies must be tested (e.g. zinc) and treated accordingly. In patients with no nutritional deficiencies,
 is a strategy that can be used for treatment, where patients are taught to redirect the undesired behavior into other activities, such as substituting a healthier food alternative to satisfy cravings.


Option Analysis

✅ Iron deficiency anemia:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Air fluid levels on abdominal radiography:
Incorrect: Certain patients with pica may develop an obstruction in the gastrointestinal tract due to swallowing abnormal things (e.g. hair). However, these patients present with signs of bowel obstruction (e.g. abdominal pain). In the absence of these symptoms, an abdominal radiograph is not indicated in this patient.  
❌ Esophageal erosions on endoscopy:
Incorrect: EGD can be used to diagnose complications of pica. For example, swallowed substances may result in esophageal erosions; however, this patient has no evidence of pain with swallowing or abdominal pain, and therefore, an EGD is not indicated. 
❌ Large blasts on peripheral blood smear:
Incorrect: Peripheral blood smear evaluation may be appropriate in individuals presenting with signs or symptoms of leukemia (e.g., fatigue, recurrent infections, petechiae). Peripheral blood smear evaluation is not indicated in patients with pica.  
❌ Esophageal varices on endoscopy:
Incorrect: Esophageal varices is one of the most common causes of hematemesis and occurs secondary to portal hypertension. However, this patient more likely has pica, and an asymptomatic endoscopy is not indicated.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl is admitted to the hospital for nutritional support after her parents brought her to the hospital earlier today due to marked dehydration and weakness. The patient has a past medical history significant for anorexia nervosa which was being treated with psychotherapy. On admission, the patient’s temperature is 36.4°C (97.5°F), pulse is 52/min, and blood pressure is 84/62 mmHg. Body mass index is 15 kg/m<sup>2</sup>. Parenteral nutritional replenishment is started. On the second day of admission, the patient is experiencing severe myalgias, paresthesias, and shortness of breath. Physical examination reveals bibasilar crackles. Laboratory evaluation reveals markedly decreased serum potassium levels and phosphorus levels. Increased secretion of which of the following hormones is most likely the cause of this patient’s current clinical condition?
questions.solution:
This patient with severe anorexia nervosa (e.g., unstable vital signs, marked dehydration) was given nutritional replacement, and shortly after, she developed massive electrolyte abnormalities and pulmonary edema. This clinical presentation is most likely due to refeeding syndrome.   

Refeeding syndrome is a potentially fatal condition that results from the rapid shift of fluids and electrolytes after the introduction of feeding in severely malnourished people (e.g. anorexia nervosa). During starvation, several intracellular electrolytes become depleted, but the serum levels of these electrolytes usually remain at normal levels because these are mainly intracellular electrolytes; these electrolytes include potassium, magnesium, phosphorus, and thiamine. After the reintroduction of food containing carbohydrates, insulin secretion is stimulated; this increase in serum insulin is the major driver of refeeding syndrome. Insulin stimulates the intracellular uptake of phosphorus to be used in the synthesis of ATP and, in addition, stimulates the uptake of potassium and magnesium. This rapid shift for the use of these electrolytes results in massive depletion of them in the intracellular and extracellular compartments, leading to hypophosphatemia, hypokalemia, and hypomagnesemia. These electrolyte imbalances are very dangerous and can lead to cardiac arrhythmias, cardiac arrest, and death.    

In addition, the rapid use of already-depleted thiamine can result in severe thiamine deficiency, causing Wernicke encephalopathy characterized by the triad of encephalopathy, ataxia, and nystagmus.  

Lastly, consumption of carbohydrates can lead to increased sodium and water retention, which is usually combined with fluid replacement to maintain urine output. These fluid shifts can lead to severe volume overload, pulmonary edema, and arrhythmias.  



Option Analysis

✅ Insulin:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Cortisol:
Incorrect: Although serum cortisol levels are elevated in patients with anorexia nervosa, cortisol does not play a significant role in the pathogenesis of refeeding syndrome.   
❌ Epinephrine:
Incorrect: Epinephrine is also sometimes increased in patients with anorexia, but it does not play a significant role in the development of refeeding syndrome.  
❌ Glucagon:
Incorrect: Glucagon is increased in patients with anorexia, but once adequate nutrition is introduced again, glucagon levels decrease, not increase.  
❌ Growth hormone:
Incorrect: Growth hormone levels are increased in patients with anorexia, but IGF-1 levels are low, indicating growth hormone resistance in these patients. However, elevated growth hormone is not associated with the development of refeeding syndrome.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the physician complaining of a depressed mood and a general lack of interest in activities she used to enjoy. The patient has been “feeling low” for the past 2 months. In addition, she also has no appetite and has noticed that her weight has decreased. She is often fatigued and has difficulty falling asleep at night. Past medical history includes bulimia nervosa and multiple sclerosis. She is not currently taking any medications. Which of the following medications is contraindicated in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient is most likely experiencing major depressive disorder (MDD) given her low mood, fatigue, abnormal appetite, anhedonia, and difficulty sleeping. Of note, she also has a history of bulimia nervosa and multiple sclerosis, which will impact the types of medications that are safe to use to treat the MDD.  

Bupropion is an antidepressant that works via inhibition of the reuptake of norepinephrine and dopamine in the central nervous system. It is frequently used in the treatment of MDD, especially in patients who are experiencing fatigue due to its stimulatory effects.    

However, bupropion can lower the threshold for seizures and is therefore contraindicated in patients with a current or previous history of bulimia nervosa or anorexia nervosa. These patients are already at increased risk of seizures due to their predisposition for electrolyte abnormalities (from purging behaviors and from malnutrition). As the use of bupropion in these patients significantly increases the risk of epileptic episodes, it is therefore strictly contraindicated.  

Option Analysis

✅ Bupropion:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Sertraline:
Incorrect: Sertraline is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) and is not contraindicated in this patient.  
❌ Tranylcypromine:
Incorrect: Tranylcypromine is a monoamine oxidase inhibitor. Although it is not used as first-line treatment of depression, it is not contraindicated in this patient. 
❌ Venlafaxine:
Incorrect: Venlafaxine is a serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SNRI). It is not contraindicated in this patient.  
❌ Fluoxetine:
Incorrect: Fluoxetine is another SSRI and is not contraindicated in this patient.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her parent due to the absence of consistent menstrual cycles. The patient has not had any menstrual cycles for the last 5 months. Menarche occurred at age 13. She has recently joined the gymnastics team at school and is trying to exercise and lose weight. Her parent is worried about her eating habits because she has been eating less to lose weight even though she is already thin. The patient tells the physician she is afraid of gaining weight and that she “does not like how her body looks.” Her BMI is 17.4 kg/m2. On physical examination, hair loss is noticed on the head, and the breasts are Tanner stage V. There is growth of soft, unpigmented hair over the arms. Which of the following hormonal changes is most likely responsible for this patient’s amenorrhea?
questions.solution:
This patient is most likely experiencing amenorrhea due to calorie restriction and weight loss secondary to an underlying diagnosis of anorexia nervosa. Anorexia nervosa is an eating disorder characterized by low body weight, a distorted body image, and an intense fear of gaining weight accompanied by aggressive weight-loss behaviors (e.g., calorie restriction, excessive exercising).    

Anorexia nervosa is associated with multiple complications in almost every organ in the body due to malnutrition and weight loss. Because of the calorie restriction and starvation, protein and fat catabolism results in atrophy in the brain, heart, intestines, muscles, and kidneys. In addition, hormonal disturbances are common in patients with anorexia. Due to severe malnutrition, the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis is often disturbed in both males and females. Patients with anorexia have decreased GnRH release, leading to decreased LH and FSH, which subsequently decreases estrogen and testosterone. This hormonal disturbance leads to infertility, decreased sexual function, and amenorrhea in females. Amenorrhea in females with anorexia nervosa is one of the most common manifestations of the condition.  

In addition, patients tend to have high cortisol and an elevated growth hormone (GH), while insulin-like growth factor-1 is low, indicating GH resistance. Finally, these patients often have thyroid hormone disturbances similar to a euthyroid sick syndrome, in which T3 is low but TSH is normal. T4 is usually variable.  

Other complications of anorexia include: 
  •  Gastrointestinal: constipation, bloating, elevated liver enzymes 
  •  Neurological: confusion, altered mental status 
  •  Dermatological: hair loss, lanugo hair growth (growth of soft, unpigmented hair), dry scaly skin  
  •  Hematological: pancytopenia 
  •  Musculoskeletal: muscle atrophy, osteopenia, osteoporosis  


Option Analysis

✅  Gonadotropin-Releasing Hormone (GnRH)  Luteinizing hormone (LH)  Estrogen   Decreased  Decreased  Decreased  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌  Gonadotropin-Releasing Hormone (GnRH)  Luteinizing hormone (LH)  Estrogen   Increased   Increased   Decreased  :
Incorrect: These labs are seen in patients with primary ovarian insufficiency; however, this patient’s amenorrhea is likely a complication of anorexia nervosa, in which calorie restrictions result in decreased GnRH release, with subsequent decreases in LH and estrogen, and resultant anovulation.
❌  Gonadotropin-Releasing Hormone (GnRH)  Luteinizing hormone (LH)  Estrogen   Normal   Normal   Normal  :
Incorrect: The patient in this vignette is most likely suffering from anorexia nervosa, wherein there is decreased GnRH, LH, and estrogen. 
❌  Gonadotropin-Releasing Hormone (GnRH)  Luteinizing hormone (LH)  Estrogen   Increased  Decreased  Decreased  :
Incorrect: These labs indicate a pituitary pathology causing amenorrhea. This patient’s presentation is most consistent with anorexia nervosa, which causes a different set of laboratory abnormalities. 
❌  Gonadotropin-Releasing Hormone (GnRH)  Luteinizing hormone (LH)  Estrogen   Increased  Increased  Increased  :
Incorrect: This patient has amenorrhea, indicating decreased gonadotropic hormones, not increased.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parent due to “bad breath.” The patient tells the physician that he has had a foul-smelling odor and taste in his mouth for the past month. The patient also tells the physician he is feeling ashamed of himself because “I can’t control my eating sometimes.” He describes frequent episodes in which he will eat multiple bags of chips within several minutes, followed by an intense feeling of guilt. He has no past medical history. The patient’s height is 165 cm and his weight is 65 kg. He is in the 50th percentile for height and 75th percentile for weight, both of which have remained the same since his last visit 6 months ago. Oral examination reveals multiple dental caries as well as erosion of the enamel. Hand examination reveals calluses on the knuckles. Which of the following medications is contraindicated given this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient most likely has bulimia nervosa. Bulimia nervosa is an eating disorder characterized by binge-eating episodes followed by compensatory behaviors to prevent weight gain. During binge-eating episodes, patients lose control of overeating and consume a larger than average amount of food. These episodes are then followed by feelings of guilt and compensatory behaviors to prevent weight gain; these behaviors include purging (inducing vomiting), use of laxatives, diuretics, extreme exercises, or prolonged fasting.    

Clinical features of bulimia nervosa include dental complications, especially in those who induce vomiting. The chronic exposure of teeth to gastric acids can result in enamel erosion and dental caries. Additionally,  a nearly pathognomonic dermatologic complication is calluses on the dorsum of the hand (Russell sign), due to pressure of the teeth against the skin while stimulating the gag reflex to induce vomiting. For a diagnosis of bulimia nervosa, these episodes must occur at least once per week, for at least 3 months.    

The difference between bulimia nervosa and anorexia nervosa binge-eating/purging subtype is body weight; patients with anorexia have low body weight (BMI <18.5), while patients with bulimia nervosa have a normal weight and are sometimes overweight.     

It is important to consider an eating disorder such as bulimia nervosa in any patient presenting with a characteristic history and physical exam, such as this patient – regardless of gender. While eating disorders are more common in women, girls, and transgender individuals, men and boys are still subsceptible to these potentially fatal conditions and are often underdiagnosed. It is therefore important to avoid stereotyping when formulating a differential diagnosis for a patient presenting with disordered eating behaviors.  

The treatment of bulimia nervosa is aimed towards decreasing binge-eating and purging behaviors. Fluoxetine is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) that has been shown to have great efficacy in patients with bulimia; it is considered a first-line treatment as it is associated with decreased binge-eating and purging episodes. Trazodone can also be used in patients with bulimia nervosa, and it has been shown to decrease the binge-eating and purging behavior, but patients must be monitored for side effects, such as weight loss. Of note, buproprion is contraindicated in patients with eating disorders as its administration may precipitate seizures, and these patients are already at increased risk of seizures given their predisposition to electrolyte imbalances from purging or malnutrition.    

In addition to pharmacological interventions, patients with bulimia nervosa are also treated with cognitive behavioral therapy and interpersonal therapy. The combination of psychotherapy and pharmacotherapy has been shown to provide the best outcomes in patients with bulimia nervosa.




Option Analysis

❌ Fluoxetine :
Incorrect: Fluoxetine is the first-line treatment of bulimia nervosa and can be used alone or in combination with cognitive-behavioral therapy.  
✅ Bupropion:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Tranylcypromine:
Incorrect: Tranylcypromine is a monoamine oxidase inhibitor. It is not a first-line treatment of bulimia nervosa because of its severe side-effects, but it is not strictly contraindicated.  
❌ Lisdexamfetamine:
Incorrect: Lisdexamfetamine can be used in the management of binge-eating disorder. It has no role in the treatment of bulimia nervosa, but it is not technically contraindicated. 
❌ Olanzapine:
Incorrect: Olanzapine can sometimes be used to stimulate weight gain in patients with severe anorexia nervosa who do not respond well to nutritional rehabilitation and psychotherapy. It is not strictly contraindicated in patients with bulimia nervosa.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman comes to the physician due to increased weight. The patient tells the physician that she sometimes cannot control herself when she eats and consumes large amounts of food. She also states that she prefers eating alone because she feels ashamed of her eating habits. She does not use laxatives or diuretics, and she also does not engage in purging behavior. Vitals are within normal limits. Body mass index is 33 kg/m<sup>2</sup>. The physician discusses with the patient the use of cognitive-behavioral therapy, and she asks if there is any medication that can be used to aid in weight loss. The patient is provided with a medication that blocks the reuptake of norepinephrine and dopamine in the central nervous system. Which of the following medications was provided to this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient most likely has binge eating disorder. Binge eating disorder is an eating disorder that occurs most frequently in women, with a median age around 23. It is characterized by episodes of binge eating where the patient cannot control themself and often consumes larger than needed amounts of food. These episodes are then followed by feelings of regret and shame; however, unlike bulimia nervosa, patients with binge eating disorder do not engage in compensatory behaviors to prevent weight gain (e.g., purging, laxative use). Frequently, because these patients feel ashamed of their eating behaviors, they may avoid eating with others and prefer eating alone. These episodes must occur at least once per week for 3 months for the diagnosis to be made.  

Patients with binge eating disorder are usually overweight, but they can be a normal weight. These patients are at increased risk of diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, and hypertension. Additionally, these patients are at increased risk of developing depression, which may progress to suicidal ideation or attempts.  


Treatment of binge eating disorder aims to decrease the binge eating episodes and stimulate weight loss in overweight patients. The use of cognitive behavioral therapy and psychotherapy has been shown to be of great significance in reducing binge eating habits and is, therefore, the first-line treatment. Pharmacotherapy can be used, especially in patients who are not able to attend cognitive behavioral therapy, or in those who require medical assistance with weight loss. Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors can be used in patients with binge-eating disorder. In addition, lisdexamfetamine is a stimulant that can be used to achieve weight loss in patients with binge eating disorder.  

 PS: If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741.  



Option Analysis

✅ Lisdexamfetamine:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Tranylcypromine:
Incorrect: Tranylcypromine is a monoamine oxidase inhibitor. The medication described in this stem is a stimulant medication.  
❌ Haloperidol:
Incorrect: Haloperidol is an antipsychotic medication that can be used in combination with psychotherapy in patients with anorexia nervosa to stimulate weight gain. This medication is a pure dopamine receptor antagonist.  
❌ Olanzapine:
Incorrect: Olanzapine is an antipsychotic medication that can be used in combination with psychotherapy in patients with anorexia nervosa to stimulate weight gain.  
❌ Terbutaline:
Incorrect: Although beta-agonists can induce weight loss, they should not be used for this purpose.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents due to concerns about her attitude over her weight. The parents tell the physician that their daughter is always concerned about her weight and measures her weight multiple times per day. The patient reports that she feels she is overweight, and she feels ashamed of her body. Vitals are within normal limits. The patient is 166 cm (65.4 inches) and her weight is 50 kg (110-lbs). Physical examination reveals a thin-appearing female. Oropharyngeal examination reveals multiple damaged molars with several dental caries. The parotid glands appear mildly enlarged. Hand examination reveals calluses over the knuckles. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient, who has low body weight, distorted body image, and signs of purging behavior, most likely has anorexia nervosa (AN).    

AN is an eating disorder seen more commonly in females; specifically, its highest prevalence is among teenage girls. AN is characterized by the extreme overvaluation of body shape and weight, with intense fear to gain weight. Patients with anorexia nervosa have low body weight which is defined by a body mass index (BMI) below 18.5 kg/m2 (or in younger children, body weight below the 5th percentile for age). This patient’s calculated BMI is 18.1 kg/m2.    

Despite their low BMI, these patients have a distorted self-image and are consistently trying to lose more weight or maintain a low body weight. To that end, patients with the restricting subtype may engage in a restrictive pattern of eating wherein they avoid calorie-rich food and engage in intense calorie counting or portion eating. In the purging subtype, patients compensate for eating by purging (i.e. inducing vomiting) or using laxatives or diuretics. In addition, patients with anorexia may exercise aggressively to lose additional calories.  

The diagnostic criteria for anorexia nervosa involves  
  •  Distorted self-image  
  •  Low body weight (i.e <18.5 BMI or less than 5th percentile of weight for age)  
  •  Excessive attempts to lose weight (restriction of calories, purging) 
  Without treatment, anorexia nervosa can have an all-cause mortality rate of up to 14 times that of the general population, with 60 percent of deaths in patients with AN attributable to medical complications from the disorder (e.g. cardiovascular). It is therefore critically important to recognize and treat AN as early as possible. The core of the treatment of anorexia nervosa is nutritional rehabilitation and psychotherapy. Some patients who are suicidal or have medical complications (e.g. severe electrolyte disturbances) may need hospitalization. Although medical treatment for weight gain is not indicated initially, patients who are acutely ill and do not respond to first-line treatment may be given olanzapine to stimulate weight gain.  



Option Analysis

✅ Anorexia nervosa :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Bulimia nervosa:
Incorrect: Although patients with bulimia nervosa might show signs of purging (e.g., dental caries, calluses on the hands) as seen in this patient, patients with bulimia nervosa have a normal body mass index, unlike this patient, who has a calculated BMI of 18.1 kg/m2.  
❌ Normal adolescent behavior:
Incorrect: This patient has low body weight and a distorted body image, and she shows signs of purging behavior (e.g., dental caries, calluses on the hands). These findings suggest anorexia nervosa and should not be ignored.  
❌ Major depressive disorder:
Incorrect: Patients with major depressive disorder (MDD) may have decreased appetite, which may lead to weight loss, and they may have low self-esteem. However, this patient’s presentation suggests anorexia nervosa, given her distorted body image, low body weight and signs of purging behavior. 
❌ Picky eating disorder:
Incorrect: Picky eating disorder involves rejection of familiar and unfamiliar foods because the patients dislike the taste or the texture of certain foods. Unlike anorexia nervosa, these patients do not cut down on food to lose weight and do not have a distorted body image.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her roommate following an episode of hematemesis. Upon arrival at the hospital, the patient complains of intense lower chest pain. She describes that she first vomited green vomitus which turned red soon afterward. She does not take any medications. Her roommate privately states to the physician that the patient has a history of episodes of binge-eating, followed by periods of strict fasting for several days. Temperature is 36.4°C (97.5°F), a pulse is 82/min and blood pressure is 114/82 mmHg. BMI is 22 kg/m2. Physical examination reveals eroded dental enamels and calluses on the dorsum of the right hand. The spleen and liver are not palpable. IV fluids are initiated. After an hour, the patient has stopped vomiting but still feels chest pain. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s hematemesis?

choices.text: Longitudinal tear in the lower esophagus due to repeated forceful vomiting
Ruptured esophageal varices secondary to portal hypertension
Ulcer in the gastric antrum due to Helicobacter pylori infection
Esophageal ulcers secondary to herpes simplex virus infection
Gastric ulcer secondary to repeated use of Ibuprofen

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting to the hospital with hematemesis and intense chest pain. In addition, she has calluses on the dorsum of her hand (Russell’s sign) and eroded dental enamels, suggesting that she has been repeatedly inducing vomiting. Given her normal body weight and history of binging and purging behaviors, she most likely has bulimia nervosa. Therefore, the most likely cause of her hematemesis is Mallory-Weiss syndrome, which is a complication of repeated induced vomiting in patients with bulimia nervosa.  

Patients with bulimia nervosa can develop multiple complications. Because of repeated vomiting, patients can develop sialadenosis which manifests as bilateral swelling of the parotid glands. Due to chronic exposure of the teeth to gastric acids, patients may also develop enamel erosions, dental caries, and halitosis. In the case of manual induction of emesis, calluses may appear on the knuckles of the hands due to repeated friction with the teeth. Finally, repeated forceful emesis can sometimes lead to tears in the lower esophagus, causing hematemesis and chest pain; this complication is known as Mallory-Weiss syndrome.  



Furthermore, patients with bulimia nervosa can have multiple electrolytes abnormalities. Dehydration is often seen and can lead to metabolic alkalosis, which is worsened by repeated vomiting. Also, repeated vomiting causes loss of potassium and chloride, leading to hypokalemia and hypochloremia. Hypokalemia in particular is worrisome because it can lead to multiple complications including muscle weakness and fatal arrhythmias (e.g. ventricular tachycardia).  


Other complications of bulimia nervosa include hormonal irregularities, which develop secondary to suppression of gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) release due to calorie restrictions and extreme exercising. This suppression results in anovulation in females, leading to subsequent menstrual irregularities. Diabetes mellitus is also sometimes seen in patients with bulimia nervosa.



Option Analysis

✅ Longitudinal tear in the lower esophagus due to repeated forceful vomiting  :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Ruptured esophageal varices secondary to portal hypertension :
Incorrect: Ruptured esophageal varices are one of the most common causes of hematemesis and occur secondary to portal hypertension. However, this patient does not have signs of portal hypertension (e.g. splenomegaly); instead, the eroded dental enamels and calluses on the hands suggest repeated induced vomiting, which can lead to Mallory-Weiss syndrome.  
❌ Ulcer in the gastric antrum due to Helicobacter pylori infection:
Incorrect: Peptic ulcer disease is one common cause of hematemesis. However, this patient is most likely suffering from Mallory-Weiss syndrome secondary to repeated purging behavior given the physical findings (e.g., calluses on the hands, eroded dental enamels) and history of binge-eating with compensatory behaviors (e.g., strict fasting, purging). 
❌ Esophageal ulcers secondary to herpes simplex virus infection:
Incorrect: Esophageal ulcers caused by HSV are seen almost exclusively in immunodeficient patients (e.g. patients with AIDS). This patient does not have signs of immunodeficiency, and the physical findings suggest bulimia nervosa, in which repeated induced vomiting can lead to Mallory-Weiss syndrome and subsequent hematemesis.  
❌ Gastric ulcer secondary to repeated use of Ibuprofen:
Incorrect: NSAID-induced gastric ulcer can lead to hematemesis and abdominal pain. However, it is unlikely to be the cause of hematemesis in this patient given she is not taking NSAIDs. In addition, Mallory-Weiss syndrome is a more likely diagnosis in this case given her history and physical findings suggestive of bulimia nervosa.
